H0.text: Upper atmospheric disturbances cause tides to occur in the oceans at regular times every day.

H1.text: The tilt of Earth's rotational axis causes tides to occur in the oceans at regular times every day.

H2.text: Density differences caused by temperature changes are the reason tides occur in the oceans at regular times every day.

H3.text: The gravitational pull of the Sun and the Moon causes tides to occur in the oceans at regular times every day.

A4.text: Tides are the rise and fall of sea levels caused by the combined effects of the gravitational forces exerted by the Moon (and to a much lesser extent, the Sun) and are also caused by the Earth and Moon orbiting one another.

A5.text: Because the gravitational field created by the Moon weakens with distance from the Moon, it exerts a slightly stronger than average force on the side of the Earth facing the Moon, and a slightly weaker force on the opposite side. The Moon thus tends to 'stretch' the Earth slightly along the line connecting the two bodies.
